title: Thursday, 7th July, 2016

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 288.70, down 5.4 (-1.84%), High: 300.60, Low: 285.20, Volume: 6.32m
PM

Rubbish Q1s here: http://www.investe...1607070700085093D/

BE

Usual excuses. Weather, and Easter coming at an awkward time ..

11:14 am
BE

And management tinkering again with promotional strategy.

BE

Which -- sorry to repeat myself here -- is surely just what management should be doing.

BE

Printing rubbish sales and saying "oh, we tried not to push so much stuff out at 50% off this quarter" is an unacceptable excuse, to my mind.

11:16 am
BE

Not least because there doesn't seem to ever be a time when a retailer says "we've got the promotional stance correct, we're good now"

BE

Debenhams, for instance. Constantly saying it's not going to put the sales bunting up so often, then doing so anyway.

BE

Let me stop waffling and get some sellside.

11:16 am
PM

ok

BE

Credit Suisse is the first to appear, so here's them.

BE

The key GM LFL was -8.9% (CS -6%, Bloomberg consensus -5%): We
knew that the prior year (a soft LFL of -4%) did include a week of the summer
sale which started on July 5th this year, and reduced promotions which may
have accounted for as much as 5% of the decline. It was also clear that this
year has been extremely difficult. Nevertheless this is still a poor
performance and asks questions as to how much benefit it has seen from re-
pricing at opening price points.

11:19 am
BE

FY guidance (which includes GM gross margin +50-100bp) has been
maintained, however we remain increasingly concerned about the impact of
clearance. There is no comment on inventory levels but we assume that
stock going into quite a late sale was up Y/Y, and M&S is having to compete
with soft demand, high levels of promotions across the High Street,
collections which have not resonated and clearance by BHS and Austin
Reed.

BE

Food LFL was -0.9% (CS & consensus 0%): Given the negative calendar
effect from Easter and a tough market this was a reasonable performance,
albeit recent Kantar data suggested that it might have been a bit better. UK
sales were -1.1% with LFL -4.3%. Given the acceleration in opex
associated with NLW and commitment to restore store service levels, our
forecast of 100bp decline in UK EBIT is demanding. Intnl sales were +0.7%
on cc basis, slightly better than our -2% forecast.

BE

We remain structurally bearish on M&S particularly given the lack of
progress on restructuring the store park, which will only get harder to
achieve post Referendum. There will be optical support from the dividend
yield of 9.4% (inc special dividends) and FCF yield of 11.6%. However with a
payout ratio of near 100% and underinvestment, one has to question the
sustainability of either.

11:19 am
BE

And Barclays' conference call bullet points.

BE

Key highlights:

1. GM -5% negative impact from less promotions and timing of sale in the quarter. Impact of the latter was bigger.

2. GM pricing: 15% price reductions in 30% of the range. Price elasticity of demand favorable so far.

3. In clothing April was soft, May was better and June was weak because of M&S’s decision to promote less and later.

4. In GM, assumption that sales run 3% below market growth (currently flat) still holds.

5. Inventory volumes are up y/y a bit more than ideal but manageable.

6. GM gross margin to be weaker in 1H and stronger in 2H

7. Food deflation running at -1%.

8. 70% of Food product is fresh/chilled sourced in the UK so FX impact minimum.

9. 80% hedged for FY17, 20% hedged for AW17.

10. Online has been a tougher market the last two quarters as lack of promotions from M&S’s side has a disproportionately negative impact.

PM

See Freddie George is now a quite aggressive seller

11:20 am
PM

Cantor man

PM

Marks & Spencer (SELL) – Q1 trading update
MKS LN (298p, TP 250p from 400p), Market Cap: £4,836m

PM

Our view: The stock is likely to remain unloved after this update. We still have concerns that the company will not be able to reverse the declines in General Merchandise (GM) LFL sales while the rate of growth in GM gross margins is likely to slow. In the meantime, the Food division will face a more competitive market and net debt remains stubbornly above £2bn. We reiterate our SELL recommendation but downgrade our TP to 250p from 400p.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 290.00, up 11.1 (+3.98%), High: 324.00, Low: 277.10, Volume: 1.97m
BE

Just wanted to make that clear, to any lawyers reading.

11:24 am
PM

Not sure what you are saying there Bryce

BE

Good.

BE

So FY in line. FX warning in 16-17.

11:25 am
BE

Sports Direct being extremely exposed to cable via its sourcing via Indonesia, Pakistan and the like, of course.

BE

RBS sees the stock as a call option on cable.

BE

Sports Direct has reported underlying EBITDA of £381mn, broadly in line with our £380mn estimate, but slightly higher than consensus of £368mn. Sports
Retail revenue was slightly higher than forecast, Brands revenue lower and net debt at £100mn slightly lower than forecast. However as expected SPD has
issued a cautious outlook statement given the recent stronger dollar trend versus sterling, pressures on high street footfall and political and economic
uncertainty. Founder Mike Ashley has stated he has no intention of taking the company private but the company has said it is considering a share buyback
which is what it did after the global financial crisis in 2009/10.
Given higher dollar sourcing and labour costs and ongoing tough UK and international trading conditions we expect further consensus EPS downgrades for
FY17 and FY18. Sports Direct is unhedged below $1.6:£1 and it buys the majority of own label product (50% of total sales) in USD from Asia. We expect higher
labour costs following the parliamentary review into SPD’s labour practices and the introduction of the national living wage.

We think International has remained challenging owing to a tough and increasingly promotional environment in Austria where SPD’s own brands have struggled
to gain traction.
There is a results meeting at 9.30am today. At the results we shall be looking for comments on relationships and availability of product from Nike and adidas which has helped to explain SPD’s underperformance versus JD over the past two years.

11:26 am
BE

Our view: Sector Perform, 325p PT - Sports Direct has a strong position in UK sports retailing and asset backing from strategic stakes in other retailers, but
international expansion is proving more challenging than we expected and it faces strong margin headwinds from FY17. SPD is the worst performing stock in
the sector year to date (-50%) and is trading on c.10x CY17E P/E compared to the sector average of 12.7x but we think FY18E consensus EPS still needs to
be revised lower – our FY18 EBITDA forecast is c.18% below the Bloomberg “consensus”.

PM

I'm sure there are cleaner ways to get a call option n GBK

PM

Rather than sport tat and bits of Debenhams

11:28 am
BE

Well, yes. There are a few variables involved with investing in a plimsoll retailer majority owned by a rather bruising chap who'll use your money to punt randomly on sector peers.

BE

Morgan Stanley as well, since we're here.

BE

- Although Net Debt has increased by £40m YoY, this represents only 0.3x
EBITDA. Hence, additionally today the company is announcing that it is
considering commencing a share buyback programme (but Mike Ashley is
confirming that he has no intention of taking the company private).
- We have not spoken with the company this morning, but it states that the
outlook for FY16/17 is "somewhat uncertain and therefore hard to predict". As
stated on the 24th June, Sports Direct has no hedging on dollar purchases for
FY16/17 or beyond. Although gross margin expectations have already been
lowered to somewhat reflect this, we believe there could be further downside
(the company exposed at 1.60), especially as the dollar continues to appreciate.
Current consensus forecasts are for FY16/17 EBITDA of £360m (or 33.7p of
EPS).
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Sports
Direct is trading on 8.7x calendar 2017, 3.6x EBITDA with a 0% dividend yield.
This compares to the UK General Retail sector on 11.6x, 6.9x and 4.0%
respectively.

11:29 am
BE

- Analyst presentation (by invitation only) at 9.30am at Goldman Sachs,

BE

I guess we need to note Primark.

11:31 am
Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,775, up 222 (+8.70%), High: 2,802, Low: 2,628, Volume: 837.04k
BE

BE

11:32 am
BE

Primark continues to slow, for reasons no-one can explain adequately.

BE

(See the Morgan Stanley note we wrote up a week or two ago)

BE

But FX helps bump FY guidance. As does a decent performance of the sugar business everyone now ignores.

11:00 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

While today's fx driven guidance upgrade by ABF is welcome, Primark's ability
to divorce margin trends from LFL pressures continues to puzzle us. Ultimately
we feel the valuation debate has moved onto more balanced grounds. This,
together with the clear added uncertainty from the UK consumer outlook
(and deteriorating market share performance), suggests prospects remain
unexciting.

BE

No longer expecting EPS to fall in 16/17 is the main news today from the 'marginal
decline' reiterated at the April interims. Since then £$ has gone from 1.43 to sub 1.30, while £€ crashed from 1.26 to 1.17. The translation benefit to non-UK earnings (50% of total) is meaningful and immediate. The transaction headwinds stemming from £/$ are delayed by hedges, and we expect them to impact greater than 25% of group EBIT (the UK portion of Primark EBIT) from the late stages of Q2 16/17. Look out for risks of a €$ sell-offs, which would incrementally challenge this fx equation.

11:34 am
BE

Primark defying gravity on margin. Cumulative YTD sales at Primark came in at 7%,
a little shy of our estimates. We estimate this to imply Q3 LFL to have fallen by 4%, from
-1% in H1. Mgmt highlights the self-evident weather impacts which weighed on all fashion
retailers (with the one exception of ITX). What is more surprising is Q3 EBIT margin of
11.9%, implying -50bps YoY when compared with H2 last year. This is remarkable in light
of weakening LFLs, a mid-season sharpening of price points, start-up losses from the US
and the g.m headwind of sourcing shifting from £$ of greater than 1.60 to 1.50. We estimate that had gross margin been flat and opex grown in line with space increases in Q3, then EBIT margin should have reduced by greater than 100bps. Primark has managed to deliver a remarkable outcome, and one that deserves more careful consideration.

BE

Trading at fair value to us. The trajectory of sugar profits will be clearly helpful to
group expectations into 16/17, but we estimate this to be worth less than 10% of group
FV. What is key is the 70%+ contributed to FV by Primark. The outlook on this front looks
less straightforward. We remain of the view that the valuation peaks of the past (high 30x
P/E, now 28x) will prove elusive, as multi-channel challenges offset great visibility on space
expansion.

BE

Valuation/Risks
Valuation: 2600p PT reflects a SOTP placing Primark's calendar 2017E earnings on 26x,
sugar on 10.5x and the balance on c.17x. Risks: a spike in cotton prices, a reversal in recent sugar price gains and US$ appreciation both vs £ and €.

11:35 am
undefined
BE

(@JL: Santander?)

BE

Okay, what else?

11:37 am
BE

I guess we can go through a few of the second liners.

BE

The independents have come in on Auto Trader today, and are positive.

Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 329.10, up 15.3 (+4.88%), High: 330.90, Low: 316.00, Volume: 982.53k
11:38 am
BE

Both Panmure and Canaccord rating as new buys.

BE

Here's the latter.

BE

We view the recent share price weakness as a buying opportunity. We think Auto Trader will remain relatively resilient if the autos market weakens, as a market leading online classified business model with clearly identified growth drivers and strong cost discipline. We initiate coverage with a BUY recommendation and a 395p price target, offering 25% potential upside from the current share price.

11:38 am
BE

Auto Trader is the UK's leading automotive classified website. Its traffic (47.9m average monthly visits) and listings (437,000 each day) are significantly higher than competitors', helped by strong brand awareness and consumer trust. Around 80% of all used cars sold through the motor trade appear on the site and its access to data and suite of products make it a valuable partner to retailers, providing a lucrative source of leads in a competitive market. The company has demonstrated a long history of growing revenues, and we think it has the tools to extend its track record through up-selling, cross-selling, increasing stock and targeted price increases as it delivers greater value to its partners.

FY16 results released in June were impressive. Leverage has been substantially cut since IPO, reducing the group's interest burden from 36% of sales in FY15 to a forecast 3.5% in FY17. Costs are being leveraged and operating margins growing, with over 90% of incremental revenues expected to drop through to EBITDA in the next three years. Both initiatives are facilitating a significant increase in free cash flow generation for equity holders, which rose over 140% last year. With no need for excess cash the group is using it to pay dividends (yielding 1.6% in FY17E), fund a rolling share buy-back scheme (worth 2.9% of the current market cap this year) and further reduce gearing. We anticipate shareholder returns of nearly £120m in FY17.

We think concerns over Brexit are weighing heavily on the rating - while the chance of a weaker autos market cannot be discounted the UK is coming from a place of strength. Employment has never been higher, consumers are feeling wealthier and finance is available at historically low costs. In addition, the strength and flexibility of the AUTO model, which is reliant on the less volatile used car market, together with ongoing buybacks and tight cost control should, according to our sensitivity analysis, result in continued earnings growth even in a weaker environment.

BE

Auto Trader shares many similarities with Rightmove (LSE : RMV : 3,360p | Hold, 4100p) - it is the market leader in its space, adopts a similar capital return policy, and trades on similar multiples. Our target price of 395p is based on 19.2x calendar 2017 EV/EBITDA - a 15% discount to Rightmove's one-year average EV/EBITDA multiple given the latter's more established track record and heightened macro risk post-Brexit. Quest® provides strong support to our valuation. The recent share price weakness has, in our view, created an opportunity to acquire a quality investment at an attractive entry point.

BE

Or .... one can argue that new car sales are at or around bubble volumes supported by free credit and PPI, which has fed on a delay into Auto Trader volumes making its growth look structural rather than cyclical.

11:40 am
BE

However, I'm not an analyst. What do I know? Here's Panmure.

BE

Auto Trader is a high quality business that enjoys a dominant market position.
We believe that the company is well positioned to perform against a weakening
macroeconomic backdrop considering its ability to pass on regular price
increases to retailers and given that it will benefit from the continued transition
of the vehicle buying process online and the growing need for automotive
retailers to gather data. The stock justifies a premium rating given its
defensibility and cash generation; we therefore initiate coverage with a BUY
recommendation and a price target of 417p.

BE

 A strong UK car market. The UK car market has gone through a period of
unprecedented growth. Strong new car sales should flow through into the used car
market, increasing the number of vehicles listed on the Auto Trader platform.
 An ability to outperform the underlying market. Little correlation exists between
Auto Trader’s revenue growth and the number of new car transactions in the UK. This
demonstrates Auto Traders ability to maintain and improve the average monthly
revenue generated per retailer forecourt (ARPR) throughout the market cycle.
 A dominant market position. Auto Trader has a dominant market position and enjoys
leadership across consumer audience, stock volume and site visitor engagement. The
aggregator business model can be one of the most powerful and defensible models to
operate online, thus Auto Trader should be capable of maintaining its market leading
position.
 Increased cash returns. Whilst Auto trader’s current yield isn’t particularly attractive,
we see scope for the payout ratio to increase as debt is paid down. Net debt to
EBITDA is expected to fall to 1.3x through FY17 (from 3.3x in FY15) which would allow
the company to increase the payout ratio from c30% to 50%. In these circumstances,
dividend per share could increase from 4.8p to 7.2p and the yield from c1.5% to
c2.3%.
 Trading at a discount to its fundamental worth. Our cash flow analysis shows Auto
Trader’s intrinsic worth to be c£4.5bn; this equates to a value of 417p per share. This
implies that the shares are currently trading at a circa 30% discount to their
fundamental worth.

11:41 am
BE

OUR VIEW: Whilst the stock has performed well (o/p FTSE1000 by 20% YTD), valuation is not demanding compared to the other defensives in the sector
especially given higher EPS growth here, improving mix and organic growth and the acquisition opportunity. The stock trades on a 17E PE of 17x, FCF Yield
5.3%. Rentokil remains our Top Pick in the sector.

11:48 am
BE

And Stifel.

BE

The group has added c.£100m (including Residex) of annualized revenue from
20 acquisitions so far this year. We expect the group to be heading beyond its
earlier guidance of about £40-60m spend on acquisitions this year with
£70-80m now looking more likely.
The trading update highlights that only c.90% of group revenues are from
outside the UK and there is little transaction activity across borders.
Clearly a positive update. We assume that there has been no change to return
criteria on acquisitions (starting at 15% post tax IRR) – any extension of
acquisition expenditure is value accretive. With a view to risk, S&P has
removed its negative outlook from the group’s BBB debt rating.
Interims are due on 28 July. Although the stock price is closing towards our
target price, FX and the value accretion of acquisition gives upside also to that
target.

undefined
11:49 am
BE

Still among the second liners, want a Just Eat upgrade?

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 444.20, up 22.9 (+5.44%), High: 447.30, Low: 426.10, Volume: 976.02k
BE

Competition fears overplayed.

11:50 am
PM

(back)

PM

Who

PM

is this from?'

11:50 am
BE

(@ViaCon: I can't because I'm a responsible hack. Suffice to day, though, that doctors gossip a lot.)

BE

Credit Suisse.

BE

We initiate on Just Eat (JE) with an Outperform rating and 560p TP. Just
Eat operates the world's leading digital takeaway marketplace, with top
positions in 12 of its 13 markets. Although we view competition as the
group's key risk, we think these concerns are overdone given its execution
success and the growing, structurally attractive market.

11:51 am
BE

Leading positions in large and structurally growing markets. The
takeaway/delivery market is early in its structural migration online (3-45%
online, dependent on the market) affording significant growth opportunities to
Just Eat in a sector with attractive cash dynamics and significant operational
leverage at scale. We see structural growth as ordering moves online and
other revenue opportunities from monetising the wider value added by Just
Eat to its restaurants (data and efficiency tools).

BE

Competition worries seem overdone. Given low barriers to entry and high
industry returns, competition is inevitable. However, we think fears over
competition from new delivery-only logistics firms (eg Deliveroo and
UberEATS) are overdone, with these companies in fact expanding the overall
market; given high consumer costs, we view them as mainly high-end and
big-city-focused and thus not competing with Just Eat’s core business. We
also think Just Eat’s software-only model is superior to logistics infrastructure
models. We do however acknowledge risks posed by major internet players
such as Amazon.

BE

Valuation: Our SOTP puts the UK business on 17.6x '17E EBITDA, a 10%
premium to Euro internet peers; ANZ and Established businesses on a 25%
premium to Euro peers; and the Developing business on 8.3x '17E sales, a
20% discount to consensus for Rocket Internet. At our 560p TP, JE would
trade on 37x '17E P/E, a 59% premium to Euro Internet peers. We think this
is justified given its faster growth. Our blue-sky scenario envisages profits
rising ten-fold, yielding a valuation of 660p, while our grey sky is 330p. Credit
Suisse HOLT®'s warranted price is 575p, roughly in line with our TP.

11:52 am
BE
